yaml.title: PKM Workshop
yaml.subtitle: Organizing Knowledge with Logseq and Obsidian
yaml.author: Cecilia Baldoni

markdown.markdown:
[Welcome to the PKM Workshop]{.titletea .large}

- Learn how to organize knowledge effectively. - Explore powerful tools: [Logseq](https://logseq.com/) and [Obsidian](https://obsidian.md/) - Build systems that work **for you**. [Why This Workshop?]{.titletea .midi}
- **Discovering PKM** - **Reality Check**: - I was overwhelmed by the information and choices. - **Months of Trial and Error**: - It took me a long time to develop a workflow that made sense. - **Today’s Goal**: - To give you a filter and a starting kit.
[Today's Goal]{.titletea .midi} To give you a filter and a starting kit. ![Filter Information](/images/logseq_structure.png){.fragment width="1400px" height="500px"} [You are the expert]{.titletea} - No one-size-fits-all solution. - You are the expert on your own needs and workflows. - This workshop will help you: - Build a system for **your specific goals**. - Avoid the overwhelm I experienced. - A practical starting kit to take home. - An understanding of key concepts and tools. - Confidence to explore and adapt PKM further on your own. ## What is PKM? {.tea-theme} - **Definition**: - A system for **capturing**, **organizing**, and **retrieving** knowledge efficiently. - **Why PKM Matters**: - Challenges: Information overload, scattered notes, difficult retrieval. - Benefits: Boost research efficiency, streamline writing, improve focus. ## How PKM Fits Your Research Needs {.tea-theme} - **Capture Knowledge**: - Gather notes, ideas, and information. - **Organize Effectively**: - Group related items by projects, tasks, or themes. - **Retrieve Quickly**: - Find what you need when you need it. - **Collaborate Better**: - Share ideas and build connections. - **Move Projects Forward**: - Turn scattered information into tangible outcomes. ## Poll Results {.tea-theme} - **Question**: "What do you need Personal Knowledge Management for?" - **Responses**: - **Everything** ## Current Workflows and Challenges {.tea-theme} - **Reflect on Your Practices**: - Tools you use (analog or digital). - How you organize notes (folders, tags). - **Challenges**: - Losing track of papers or ideas. - Overwhelming, unstructured notes. - **Discussion**: - Share your workflows and struggles. ## Common Pitfalls in PKM {.rose-theme} - **Challenges**: - Overcomplication: Too many tools or frameworks. - Inconsistency: Poor tagging or organization habits. - Fear of starting: Blank page syndrome. - **Solutions**: - Start small. - Build workflows iteratively. - Focus on consistency. ## Tools for PKM: Logseq and Obsidian {.rose-theme} - **What are they?** - Tools designed to help you organize, connect, and retrieve knowledge. - Focused on personal workflows and flexibility. ## Why I Chose These Two {.rose-theme .incremental} ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} **Logseq**\ - Open-source.\ - Great for journaling and task management.\ - Helps build structured, hierarchical notes. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} **Obsidian**\ - Free with optional paid extras.\ - Great for visualizing connections (Graph View).\ - Flexible with many plugins. ::: ::::: ## Why Not Other Apps? {.rose-theme} - **Notion**: - Cloud-based: - Requires internet for most features. - Less privacy (your data is stored on their servers). - No true offline access. - **Paid Apps**: - Many apps (like Roam Research) require monthly subscriptions. - **These Two Work Well for Free**: - Both Logseq and Obsidian store notes locally and work offline. ## Limitations of Logseq and Obsidian - **Logseq**: - Still in beta: - Occasional bugs and incomplete features. - Limited plugin availability: - Fewer plugins compared to Obsidian. - **Obsidian**: - Plugin dependency: - Many advanced features rely on community plugins. - Less emphasis on journaling: - Focuses more on linking and long-form writing. ## Designing Your Workflow - **How to Start**: - Identify key goals. - Focus on 1-2 knowledge categories (e.g., literature, daily tasks). - **Build Iteratively**: - Customize templates, tags, and metadata. - Experiment and refine your system. ### Zettelkasten ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - **What it is**: - A German term meaning "slip-box." - Focuses on creating small, self-contained notes (atomic notes) and linking related ideas. - **Best for**: - Developing a knowledge base that fosters creativity and connections. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![Placeholder for Zettelkasten image](path/to/image) ::: ::::: ### PARA ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - **What it is**: - A system by Tiago Forte for organizing all information. - **How it works**: - Four categories: - **Projects**: Active tasks. - **Areas**: Ongoing responsibilities. - **Resources**: Reference material. - **Archives**: Completed items. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![Placeholder for PARA image](path/to/image) ::: ::::: ### Second Brain ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - **What it is**: - A framework by Tiago Forte for managing and retrieving knowledge efficiently. - **How it works**: - Captures ideas, notes, and resources in a single system. - **Best for**: - Building a personal repository of ideas and knowledge. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![Placeholder for Second Brain image](path/to/image) ::: ::::: ### Mind Mapping ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - **What it is**: - A visual approach to organizing and connecting ideas. - **How it works**: - Start with a central idea and branch out with related concepts. - **Best for**: - Brainstorming, planning, and exploring relationships visually. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![Placeholder for Mind Mapping image](path/to/image) ::: ::::: ### Smart Notes ::::: columns ::: {.column width="50%"} - **What it is**: - A note-taking philosophy from *How to Take Smart Notes* by Sönke Ahrens. - Three types of notes: - **Fleeting notes**: Quick, temporary ideas. - **Literature notes**: Summaries of readings. - **Permanent notes**: Refined ideas linked to other notes. - **Best for**: - Thinking critically and writing effectively. ::: ::: {.column width="50%"} ![Placeholder for Smart Notes image](path/to/image) ::: ::::: # {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Logseq" auto-animate="true"} [What is Logseq]{.titlerose .large} ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="What is Logseq" auto-animate="true"} [What is Logseq]{.titlerose .large}
- Open-source tool for **PKM** and **task organization** - Networked outliner - Folder agnostic
![](Logseq_files/images/logseq_structure.png){.fragment width="1400px" height="500px"} # {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}
[Outliner-Based Workflow]{.midi} ::: {.slide-content fragment-index="2"} - Structures notes into **blocks** (or *paragraphs*)
- *everything in Logseq is about the **blocks**!*
- Blocks can be nested hierarchically for: - Outlining ideas - Organizing complex thoughts - Easy to reorganize or move blocks ::: ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}
[Backlinks and Linking]{.midi}
- Create links using the `[[Link Syntax]]` - Backlinks: a link for a page that is shown to the current page - Encourages a **web of interconnected notes** ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}
[Journaling and Daily Notes]{.midi}
- Automatically creates a **daily note** - Acts as: - A chronological log. - A launchpad for other notes. ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} ![](Logseq_files/images/backlinks.png){width="1900px" height="900px"} ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}
[Task Management]{.midi}
- Integrates tasks directly into your notes: - LATER -> NOW -> DONE - TODO -> DOING -> DONE - CANCELED/CANCELLED, IN-PROGRESS, and WAIT/WAITING - Tasks can be tracked across notes using **queries**. ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}
[Task Management - Priorities]{.midi}
- ## {class="rose-theme" data-menu-title="Key Features of Logseq"} [Key Features of Logseq:]{.titlerose .large}
[Page Properties]{.midi}
- Uses **key-value pairs** for structured data: - `priority:: A deadline:: 2024-12-01` - Helps organize and filter notes based on specific criteria. ## Key Features of Logseq: Queries - Dynamically search for and display notes or tasks. - Uses **Clojure syntax** for powerful, customizable queries. - Example: {{query (and \[\[decision-making\]\] (priority A))}} ## Key Features of Logseq: Local-First and Privacy-Focused - **Notes stored locally** on your device. - Ensures privacy: - No reliance on cloud storage. - Fully functional offline. - Ideal for users valuing security and data control. # What Makes Logseq Different? - **Block-Based Organization**: - Granular control over information. - **Folderless Structure**: - Organizes dynamically using links, tags, and properties. - **Emphasis on Journaling**: - Daily notes are central to its workflow. - **Open-Source and Extensible**: - Community-driven, customizable ecosystem. - **Interconnected Knowledge**: - Builds a network of ideas, not isolated files. - **Advanced Queries**: - Extract meaningful insights with customizable searches. # Who Should Use Logseq? - Ideal for: - Researchers, students, and professionals. - Especially useful for those who: - Need **dynamic organization** of ideas. - Want a **combined journaling and task-tracking system**. - Prefer **interconnected knowledge networks**. - Require **privacy-focused, offline-friendly tools**. ## Contact - \[Your Email\] - \[Your Website or Social Media\]

metadata.subtitle: Organizing Knowledge with Logseq and Obsidian
